reviews.review_msg: One of the best chemistry profs at SFU. Prepare for some extremely random tangents. My advice for future takers of his class are that his exams (at least in 332) expect you to really understand the material so you definitely need to do more than just memorize a couple equations.
I would no sooner die before I show up to his class again.
Just buy the textbook and stay home. His lectures are giving cow.

Hands-down great professor, super helpful and a funny guy. The class was still difficult and it's best to come to class and listen to his lectures. I'd do some extra reading to be prepared for quizzes - most of the questions come directly from the textbook so that gets you prepared! He's really nice and responds to emails promptly.
Absolutely one of the best prof in SFU, I made appointment frequently, and he is so patient and caring.
Jeff is a meme lord. He also cares about his students much more than the average professor. He could work on his handwriting and file organization.

I've also had the pleasure of having him in CHEM230&459. He is amazing, approachable, funny. Overall great man and makes the subject of inorganic chemistry enjoyable. Though, I feel that I could listen to that man teach anything with his charm and humour. If ever in trouble, stop by his office and ask for help.
Excellent Prof... Best I've had at SFU so far. Crystal Clear Lectues. Exteremly easy to find and willing to spend time with students that need extra help.
It's better to read his lecture note and the online note together for better understanding. Overall i think he is the best chem 332 prof in sfu.

The trick to the course is to read his very helpful online notes in conjunction with the textbook. The textbook alone will not teach you enough. Come prepared to his office hours with questions and you should do fine. He needs to find a way to get the class more involved during lecture.

Super nice prof. He's very interested in teaching chemistry, unlike other profs in university. Seems like he's always looking to better himself as an instructor. I suck at inorganic, but I was able to learn the material no problem from his notes. Very good notes! I hope he stays at SFU and teaches some other upper level courses. A+ in my books!
This guy is basically the jimmy page of science. total rockstar
